description: From Middle English recreate, from the participle stem of Latin recreāre (“to restore”), from re- (“re-”) + creāre (“to create”).

verbs.description: recreate (third-person singular simple present recreates, present participle recreating, simple past and past participle recreated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give new life, energy or encouragement (to); to refresh, enliven.
examples: These ripe fruit […]  recreate the nostrils with their aromatick scent.
In Italy, though they bide in cities in winter, which is more gentlemanlike, all the summer they come abroad to their country-houses, to recreate themselves.
Phonecams are proliferating like mad, their tiny eyes fuzzily probing so many corners of public and private life that they have begun to alter how people communicate and recreate.

verbs.description: recreate (third-person singular simple present recreates, present participle recreating, simple past and past participle recreated)
